Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: An optional, drop-in adult education class on a general topic is scheduled.
Story: I stared at my computer screen, headset pressing into my ear, as another call connected. “Hello, this is David from BrightNet Solutions—” The woman on the other end immediately launched into a barrage of technical questions about our new service. My script only skimmed the surface, and I felt the familiar anxiety rise. I was supposed to handle objections, keep the call moving, but she wanted real answers. I glanced at the clock. In twenty minutes, I was supposed to be at the synagogue, leading the adult education class. It was optional, but I knew several regulars would be there, expecting me to guide them through the week’s Torah portion, to answer their questions with patience and depth. My supervisor’s voice echoed in my mind: “Don’t let them off the hook. Keep them engaged.” But as a rabbi, I was expected to be present, attentive, a source of wisdom and calm. My stomach twisted. I couldn’t be in two places at once, couldn’t meet both sets of expectations. The woman on the phone waited for my answer, and my phone buzzed with a reminder: “Adult Ed class in 15 minutes.” I closed my eyes, torn between two worlds.
